reviewText:
Early Access Review

Death Goat:
~~~~~~~~~~

Whether you are a goat, a witch or a granny, you have to survive as long as you can in this epic arcade action game!
Death Goat is a top down arcade action/survival type of game where you have to push back waves of enemies until you die! Basically you need to last as long as you can and score as many points as possible!!

At  the start of the game, you will have to choose between 3 different battle arena (map), then you will be presented with several characters: Death goat (of course), a witch, a kitty, a tank (when you reach 1,000,000 points) and my favourite, the granny (I always used to see my grandmothers as nasty witches, I loved them!!)! The aim of the game is to survive as long as you can by pushing back the incoming enemies waves!

You will be equipped with a shield (protection orb) and a wand at the start to eliminate all incoming foe, but be assured you will have other great weapons to help you to survive to the next wave! But will it be your last?

What I like about this game its setup as an arcade game and it is unforgiving…fun…fun! And if you like heavy metal music, you will be well served with 14 available tracks which fit this game perfectly! It is absolutely hectic stuff!

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Fun and challenging top down arcade game
-	Several characters to choose from
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	A bit repetitive

Death Goat is a fun and hectic top down arcade game…. Hard and truly addictive!

8.5/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HERE

FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

Guts, gore and Death Metal!

Inverted crosses, burning pentagrams, walking skulls with spider legs, sexy half-naked demoness, and most of all - tons of great music to accompany the senseless, yet glorious mayhem, Death Goat" has it all in spades. If you love extreme music and appreciate the imagery

recommended: but not mandatory. There is little variation to it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Death Goat is a death and metal music themed action game where your target is to beat high scores in a survival mode.
At the start you can choose from 3 maps, 4 character (+1 unlockable) and 14 different metal music. The game controls are simple,  you use a WASD to move and a mouse to shoot, aim and detonate bomb . The next wave always harder to survive than the previous, because you can find bigger amount of enemies, with always a new type of them appearing. When you kill enemies they have a chance to drop different kinds of buff for you to pick up. The graphics of game is simple but for this game style it's fitting. Music selection is nice, if you like this genre you'll probably like it.

So my verdict

+good music
+fast action
+steam achievements and trading cards

-after longer time can be a bit repetitive
-just one game mode

I think this game not want be more for what this been developed, this a simple action game when you should survive as long as possible. This game have good music and enough fats action, but after longer time can be tiresome. But if you like this style or like a metal music i think you should try this one, because the price for this not a big, also at the moment this you can get in bundle to.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

8.2/10 - Heavy Metal Meets Bullet Hell Survival

Pretty basic top-down bullet hell shooter in most regards, but this game goes from 0-60 really fast when it comes to difficulty, so that makes this quite interesting. If you don't mind dying a bunch then this game will be right up your alley!

The real highlights about this game are the funny characters and the epic heavy metal soundtrack. The music really pumps you up and adds to the experience of killing things. Developers are continuously adding content and new heavy metal tracks for our killing pleasure!

An Early Access Game to keep your eye on! Worth the Full $3!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[FULL DISCLOSURE: REVIEW COPY PROVIDED BY DEVELOPER]

Don't be fooled by the title, folks. Death Goat is this game's flagship character but every marketing bone in my body is screaming that it should be the also-selectable DEATH GRANNY, a vicious old bat that roams the wastelands with one hand steering her wheelchair and the other unloading eldritch firepower into the hordes of Hell. Such is the fear that this decrepit devil cleanser commands that the stage announcer can only bellow 'PRUUUUUNNNEEESS' before she begins smearing wandering affronts to Christ across the desert floor to a rampaging (and fully customizable) metal soundtrack.

At the moment, DEATH GOAT is a basic twin-stick shooter with a clever, albeit niche, cosmetic theme, flooding the senses with blood, bombs and breakneck music. It's obvious that there needs to be much more added to allow it to compete with other shooters at the same budget or seriously pique the interest of hardened genre fans but the core gameplay is lightning fast and, thanks to the sheer amount of times you will die, doesn't feel as stale as its current straightforward build dictates that it should. One to watch.

You can also play as a cat in a suit of armour. It... seems wrong not to mention that.

Full review below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dIcB-g0dvL0

reviewText:
Early Access Review

RELEASE THE CRACKHEADS!!!

Death Goat is a hard-core wave based twin-stick shooter where you play as a Satanic goat (or maybe someone else if you prefer, like a death metal granny in a wheel chair) shooting down hordes of demons in a wasteland of your choice. It doesn't really matter who you choose though because all the characters seem to function the same - although the tank does seem pretty difficult to monitor the protection aura level.

Death Goat also has a lot going for it music wise. If you like metal, you're going to like this. You can select what you want to listen to, or just go for shuffle track on death which is the best way to go really until you've heard it all and picked your favourite tracks in the game.

In terms of actual game play you move about on a fairly empty wasteland - there aren't any environmental obstacles like mountains; it's just you and tonnes of demons (though being in early access maybe some environmentals will be added later). The worst of all the demons you will encounter is the tiny skull spider, and although they are the easiest thing to kill, there's lots of them, and they move fast. Your character is surrounded by an aura and each time a demon touches it (regardless of its size) the aura degrades a level and that demon dies. Once the aura is gone you're ready to be eaten by the next demon you come into contact with unless you find an aura refill. If you're eaten you lose one of your three lives, and explode killing everything before respawning. I found it not uncommon to run into a couple of small spider skulls at the same time and suddenly lose all my aura. The aura could probably do with having a brief moment of invulnerability when you get touched to make the game a little fairer, but then Death Goat isn't really about being fair. As well as the aura pick-up there's also nuke style pentagrams (of which you can hold three) and various power-ups for your weapon. Weapon power-ups are timer based and do not stack which made me a bit sad when I realised I couldn't combine effects. My favourite power-up so far is what I would describe as a psychic chainsaw, though most attacks are variants on your base projectile style weapon.

Death Goat is made in Unity, and it works pretty well. It automatically detected my ideal resolution, and I haven't found any bugs or anything that makes it difficult to play. My Xbox 360 controller worked really well with Death Goat - you use the analogue sticks and the triggers only, so you never have to shift the position of your fingers. One stick to move, the other stick to shoot in a given direction, one trigger to run, and the other to pentagram (nuke). Death Goat is just pure twitch: dodge and shoot twin stick badassery.

Being in early access Death Goat shows a lot of promise, and the dev seems to be very active in the community, and the current price of $2.99USD is pretty fair. The fact that the game appears to be bug free at this point means that development is going to focus on adding new features as asked for by the community, which is pretty exciting. I'm particularly looking forward to the possibility of multiplayer modes being added.

7 out of 10 would RELEASE MORE CRACKHEADS \m/

It follows the more arcade style top-down shooter road with a score system rather than a level system with 3 lives and a lot of power ups along with a speed boost and what we can only describe as a nuclear pentagram. There’s plenty of enemy variety to keep the player coming back

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Metal, bombs, power-ups and always on the brink of death! That is what Death Goat is all about.

Pros:
- Good selection of metal
- Teaches you how to kite (walk backwards while shooting at the enemy while also avoiding damage)
- Micromanage your character to his/her fullest potential

Cons:
- Bombs. Sometimes bombs will go off twice, thus using them up (you start with three). I think there should be a one second delay each time you hit the right mouse button (bomb button)
- On the ice stage it's hard to sometimes see the power-ups due to it blending in if it's in a certain spot
- Power-ups feel too random. What I mean by that is you're going to always be looking for the shield and purple (spray gun) power-ups. The others: blue, green and orange seem to be lacking and not up to snuff with the purple power-up
- Too luck-based. If you're planning on getting a high score you're going to need luck. Now, I know a lot of people don't mind this, I just thought I'd let you know that power-ups could make or break your game. If you don't get the one(s) you need you're good as dead.
- No spawn armor. You get three lives, and if you happen to die you'll start back in the middle where you initially began. Sometimes an enemy will hit you before you even have a chance to move, thus causing you to take damage on your shield. I think there should be a 1-2 second spawn armor where you take no damage until either: a) those 1-2 seconds are up, or b) you shoot and/or use a bomb

Overall, it's a fun game worth playing. Metal + slaughter = fun, in my book. Just needs a few tweaks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mad. Stupid. Fun.


Going into Death Goat I was planning on writing a serious review but really how can you with a game such as this? It really is mad stupid fun. It's exactly the type of game that you want to play when you only have a short time available to play and want to let off some steam.

The first thing that is addictive is the music. I'm not the biggest metal fan in the world but the music in this game is absolutely perfect. And it sounds great too. Really works for it. The graphics are just fine for what the game is as well. The range of power up weapons really gives the game some variety. You'll find that you love some of them and when you misstep onto one of the ones you don't it becomes a mad scramble to find something else. Even then, however, it's more of a case of actually learning how to use that weapon efficiently rather than it being a dud weapon.

Death Goat is just a really cool game. I honestly wasn't expecting it to be as cool as what it is. It may never win awards but it'll win the heart and the admiration of much of its player base and deservedly so. At $2.99 at full price or at $2.00 during the Steam sale it's certainly worth the price of admission into this Death Goat killing spree.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can play as Grumpy Cat, killing skulls with spider legs, in a post-apocalyptic city? 666/10!

This game is a twin-stick shooter, with an awesome heavy metal theme. (The art style, music and enemies are definitely metal!) The game is pretty simple from what I have seen so far; pick a location, pick a character, and pick a heavy metal track, then start shooting demonic creatures before they can reach you. With awesome gore and blood splatter, fantastic creature designs, upside-down crosses for lives, and pentagrams for bombs, this is by far the most metal twin-stick shooter I have ever played. As a metalhead, this game appeals to me a lot, and I'd probably be willing to pay twice the asking price.

The only real negative at this point (note: it is still in early access at this point) is the lack of variety. Each location and each character affects nothing except what the location and character looks like. The locations have no unique enemies, traps, obstacles, powerups or anything else, and characters don't have different stats or abilities. (I haven't unlocked the tank, so that might be a little different.) So, it probably won't take long to get bored of. Also, if you're not a fan of blood and gore, or metal music, you should probably keep away, but then you probably should have looked at the videos and pictures and deduced that before making your way to the user reviews.

But for its price, it's definitely an easy game to recommend. Like twin-stick shooters? Like metal-themed games? If you answered yes to both, get this game. It's great for what it costs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Twin stick shooters are what they are...  If you like the concept, you have many to choose from.  Death Goat attempts to distinguish itself from the 'others' with its soundtrack, which is damn fine if you are like me, and enjoy well structured death metal.

Unfortunately, the game totally fails at executing this distinguishment by preventing you from actually listening to any of the music, forcing a restart of the song each time you lose all of your 'lives' (which takes less than three minutes, as the game is ridiculously difficult).  How hard is it to keep the music going when your character dies off?  Must be impossible, as the game has been updated several times without this (seemingly necessary) feature.

There are many other negative nuances of the game; the lack of real choice of character (it's only cosmetic), choice of map (again, cosmetic), etc...   I can't recommend it to anyone with an attention span. As a pure twin-stick shooter, I've played at least a dozen free games that are better in various ways (powerup indicators, zoom in/out capability, perk system, better sound effects/graphics, more creative weapons, and so on...)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, since music is main selling point of this game, I must say that, although I do sometimes listen to metal music (though, rock and punk are my favourite), I generally don't like death metal... Because of that, I won't be commenting music, but will talk about gameplay (or the lack of one) in the game...

Anyway, Death Goat is a simple twin stick shooter in the style of Crimsonland (that I played and loved, long time ago); So you play as a Death Goat (or as Death Granny, or Kitty, or...) and while running around relatively small area kill everything that tries to hurt you...
The controls are responsive and feel nice, graphics are ok, but screen tends to become cluttered after some time, interface is generally ok, not too pretty, but in style and readable enough...
What I did find frustrating is that hitbox for shield" is very large (as large as shield xD)
date: and you cannot just squeeze through enemies and run away. I usually like that last second squeezing about this type of games. Not a special problem
recommended: but it did get on my nerves... :)\n\nSo

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, now that I've had the chance to play a little while here are my thoughts.

It's simple, easy to pick up and a good time-killer. Keyboard + mouse or controller, both work fine. Interesting to see how they will expand on the idea.

Get an hour or two of game time out of a small price tag (in its current state).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDeath Goat is a very tough twin stick shooter with a great liscensed death metal soundtrack with a few well known artists like Kalmah and Beyond the Buried and Me. The game has a variety of characters and maps, but really only one game mode and it's pretty repetitive. If you like twin stick shooters and metal, you'll probably have some fun with it. What it does, it does well. For the price it's probably worth it for the music alone.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe music is the best thing about this game, it revs you up and gets you into the groove of the game. The graphics pretty much feels like a 80's Nintendo game. You get killed less if you stay away from the mobs and shoot,wash and repeat pretty much,you will be dead and game over fairly fast. You can select which music you want, where you want to fight, wasteland etc. and what character you want to use as well. Still a good game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun twin-stick shooter with a great metal soundtrack to boot, with music by Between the Buried and Me, Holy Grail and many other great bands.

Slaying hordes of demons was never this fun, and it's pretty difficult until you get used to it.
It's a steal for 2€, and even though it's still Early Access it's definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Technically, a lot of big, moderately slow moving circular hitboxes, homing in on your relatively big, and moderately fast moving circular hitbox. The UI elements are named moderately amusing, but it scales badly at a 5:4 resolution, clipping out of the screen left and right.

I wouldn't recommend this game, it wasn't fun for me at all. Not the first few minutes, and not the last few minutes where I tried again to give it one more chance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sadly, this game's faults outweigh the few positives. On the plus side, the soundtrack is pretty neat, and they are continuing trying to expand it. The game runs smoothly, which is nice.

Then we go to all of the negatives. The combat feels weak. The sound design is poor, and lackluster. The enemy design tries to look cool, but it just lacks that special oomph" when you're splattering them. This game tries to copy Crimsonland and manages to be worse in every way except for the soundtrack."
